snippet: A Pew Charitable Trusts study found some big banks still reorder transactions in a way that maximizes overdraft fees, though changes have been made.
abstract: Pew Charitable Trusts study finds that some big banks still reorder daily transactions in way that maximizes potential overdraft fees, despite many ways around this policy; critics of 'high to low' practice say it can result in multiple charges set off by small purchases, like buying cup of coffee, resulting in average $35 overdraft fee, especially problematic for young and lower-income customers.
lead_paragraph: A Pew Charitable Trusts study found some big banks still reorder transactions in a way that maximizes overdraft fees, though changes have been made.

headline.main: Customers Can Lose When Banks Shuffle Payments
headline.print_headline: Customers Can Lose When Banks Shuffle Payments
